channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Helicopter Crash in Ukraine Kills at Least 14, Including Cabinet Official
item.description: It was not immediately clear what caused the helicopter crash, near a kindergarten, but there were no initial signs that it had been shot down.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Israel’s Supreme Court Orders Removal of a Netanyahu Minister
item.description: The Supreme Court ruled that Aryeh Deri, a close ally of the prime minister who was convicted of tax fraud, should be removed from his posts, as the government tries to restrict the courts’ powers.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu with Aryeh Deri, the leader of the ultra-Orthodox Shas party, during a cabinet meeting this month in Jerusalem.

item.title: Untested German Defense Minister Has Allies Watching Closely
item.description: Boris Pistorius, the new defense minister, is seen as a skilled politician but, entering a world stage on which Ukraine is at war, he may pose a risk for Chancellor Olaf Scholz.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Boris Pistorius, Germany’s new defense minister, in Lower Saxony on Tuesday.

item.title: A Shrinking, Aging China May Have Backed Itself Into a Corner
item.description: A demographics challenge has been building for years, but Beijing’s preparations are lagging. Now, many worry that current measures may offer too little, too late.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley, Joy Dong and Amy Chang Chien
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: Babies hold Chinese flags during a holiday celebration in Beijing in 2019. A declining birthrate and aging population have thrust China into a demographic bind.

item.title: Sister André, World’s Oldest Known Person, Dies at 118
item.description: The French nun had lived through two world wars and the 1918 flu pandemic. She survived Covid and was said to enjoy a daily dose of wine and chocolate.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: Sister André at the Ste. Catherine Labouré nursing home in Toulon, France, last year. She was known for her generosity.

item.title: Renting as a Single Woman in India: No Visitors, No Drinking, Home by 9
item.description: India says it must do more to harness women’s economic potential. A good place to start, many say, would be the many obstacles they face outside the workplace.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.media:credit: Saumya Khandelwal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meera Shankar, center, rents rooms to women, with no curfew or visiting rules, in her Bengaluru apartment. Cooking with her were Navya V.P., left, and Vandana Naugain.

item.title: Maria Ressa, Philippine Journalist, Is Acquitted of Tax Evasion
item.description: The verdict was a rare legal victory for Ms. Ressa, founder of the news site Rappler, who has been under pressure from the Philippine authorities for years.
item.dc:creator: Jason Gutierrez and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Maria Ressa after her acquittal in Manila on Wednesday. “Hope,” she said of the verdict. “That is what it provides.”

item.title: Why China’s Shrinking Population Is Cause for Alarm
item.description: China struggled for years to curtail its rapid population growth. Now that its population is declining, economists and others fear serious implications for China and countries around the world.
item.dc:creator: Nicole Hong
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family cradling their child at a park in Beijing. Data released this week by the Chinese government revealed that the country’s population has begun to shrink.

item.title: Covid Workers in China Clash With Police Over Unpaid Wages, Layoffs
item.description: Companies that reaped windfalls helping the government implement strict ‘zero Covid’ controls are now struggling to pay and keep workers.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson, Keith Bradsher and Muyi Xiao

item.title: China Returns to Davos With Clear Message: We’re Open for Business
item.description: Emerging from coronavirus lockdown to a world changed by the war in Ukraine, China sought to convey reassurance about its economic health.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: Mr. Liu speaking on Tuesday.

item.title: Renewed Armenia-Azerbaijan Conflict Underlines Russia’s Waning Influence
item.description: Russia helped end a 2020 war and its troops policed the cease-fire. But with a new crisis in the Caucasus heating up, Moscow, distracted and weakened by Ukraine, has not intervened.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Russian peacekeepers blocking a road outside Stepanakert, the biggest city in the Nagorno-Karabakh region, in December.

item.title: How a Kyiv School Stays in Session Amid Airstrikes and Blackouts
item.description: In Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, Russian strikes and power outages are part of the school day. Teachers and students press on with resolve.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia and Laura Boushnak
item.media:description: Students used their flashlights and smartphones at their school’s shelter during an air raid siren and a blackout, in Kyiv, Ukraine, in December.

item.title: European Parliament Corruption Suspect Cuts Deal With Prosecutors
item.description: A former European lawmaker described as key to an alleged cash-for-influence operation by Morocco and Qatar has signed an agreement with the Belgian authorities.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Marc Dossmann/European Union, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Pier Antonio Panzeri, an Italian former lawmaker in the European Parliament, in Strasbourg in 2019. Mr. Panzeri and several others are accused of accepting bribes from Qatar and Morocco.

item.title: Iranian-American Prisoner in Tehran Starts Hunger Strike
item.description: Siamak Namazi, an Iranian-American businessman, appealed to President Biden to negotiate with the government in Tehran for his freedom.
item.dc:creator: Cora Engelbrecht
item.media:description: Siamak Namazi in San Francisco in 2006.

item.title: Helicopter Crash Kills Ukrainian Minister in Blow to Wartime Leadership
item.description: The crash in a suburb of Kyiv killed at least 14 people, officials said, including the interior minister, a top adviser to President Volodymyr Zelensky, who oversaw Ukraine’s domestic security.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Megan Specia
item.category: Servant of the People (Ukrainian Political Party)
item.media:description: The scene of the helicopter crash on Wednesday in Brovary, Ukraine.

item.title: Jacinda Ardern to Resign as Prime Minister of New Zealand
item.description: Ms. Ardern, a global liberal icon who has faced rising political headwinds at home, will leave office on Feb. 7, she said.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: New Zealand’s prime minister, Jacinda Ardern, in November.

item.title: Canada’s New Guidelines for Alcohol Say ‘No Amount’ Is Healthy
item.description: The guidance builds on growing evidence, after decades of sometimes conflicting research, that even small amounts of alcohol can have serious health consequences.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Jen Osborne for The New York Times
item.media:description: Drinking even small amounts of alcohol “is damaging to everyone, regardless of age, sex, gender, ethnicity, tolerance for alcohol or lifestyle,” the Canadian Centre on Substance Use and Addiction said in a report.

item.title: At Wartime Davos Forum, Calls for European Unity Are Eased by Relief
item.description: “Our energy supply for this winter is secure,” Germany’s chancellor declared as government and business leaders gathered at the World Economic Forum.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Eshe Nelson
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany at the World Economic Forum in Davos on Wednesday.

item.title: Russian Officials Denounce Aleksei Navalny’s Treatment in Prison
item.description: Their open letter to President Vladimir V. Putin is the latest in a series of public appeals from within Russia, despite his crackdown on dissent.
item.dc:creator: Anushka Patil and Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Russian opposition leader Aleksei A. Navalny in court via video in May last year.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: A Deadly Helicopter Crash in Ukraine
item.description: Also, why economists are alarmed about China’s demographic crisis.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Firemen and emergency service workers respond at the site of a helicopter crash on Wednesday in Brovary, Ukraine.

item.title: The Only H.I.V. Vaccine in Advanced Trials Has Failed. What Now?
item.description: Janssen Pharmaceuticals ended a global trial after independent experts determined the vaccine was not effective. But there are other possibilities in the pipeline, scientists said.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:description: Study of an experimental H.I.V. vaccine in Shoshaguve, South Africa, in 2016. The vaccine has now failed in a larger trial.

item.title: Russian Citizen Accused of Running Cryptocurrency Exchange Used by Criminals
item.description: The charges were part of an intensifying effort by federal law enforcement agencies, in conjunction with European partners, to combat international cryptocurrency schemes and illegal transactions.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department said the Russian citizen, Anatoly Legkodymov, oversaw an exchange that knowingly enabled criminals “to profit from their wrongdoing, including ransomware and drug trafficking.”

item.title: U.S. Warms to Helping Ukraine Target Crimea
item.description: The Biden administration is considering the argument that Kyiv needs the power to strike at the Ukrainian peninsula annexed by Russia in 2014.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: Crimea is home to tens of thousands of Russian troops and numerous Russian military bases.

item.title: The Power Politics of Social Change
item.description: From civil rights and apartheid to the protest movements of today.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: Israelis protesting against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s new right-wing coalition in Tel Aviv on Saturday.

item.title: At Davos, Zelensky Mourns the Dead and Pleads for Help
item.description: At the start of his address, the Ukrainian president called for a minute of silence to honor the country’s minister of internal affairs.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine started his speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, with a moment of silence for those killed in Wednesday’s helicopter crash in Brovary.

item.title: A French City Appeals to Madonna for Clues About a Long-Lost Painting
item.description: The painting “Diana and Endymion” disappeared from Amiens, France, more than a century ago. The city’s mayor says Madonna could hold a key to the mystery, but experts say the pop icon has nothing to do with it.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross

item.title: China’s Self-inflicted Pain
item.description: China’s rise seemed inevitable, but now it’s hitting serious roadblocks.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Morning commuters in Shanghai last September.

item.title: Tinkering with tape, a scale and a 3-D printer, one Ukrainian unit is on a quest to build the perfect grenade.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Natalia Yermak
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A private in the Ukrainian Army attaching a grenade to a drone in August before using it on a mission over Russian frontline positions near Pokrovske, Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine Minister Killed in Helicopter Crash Oversaw Some Security Forces
item.description: Denys Monastyrsky was the highest-ranking Ukrainian government official to die since Russia’s invasion began in February last year.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Denys Monastyrsky, Ukraine’s minister for internal affairs, who was killed in a helicopter crash on Wednesday.

item.title: Zelensky will address the Davos gathering in a marathon week of diplomacy.
item.dc:creator: Carly Olson
item.media:description: Olena Zelenska, the wife of President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: China puts on a brave face at Davos.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Liu He, a senior Chinese official, expressed confidence in his country’s economy.

item.title: Pentagon Sends U.S. Arms Stored in Israel to Ukraine
item.description: Israeli officials had initially expressed concerns that the move could damage its relations with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt, Adam Entous, Ronen Bergman, John Ismay and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Arming the Ukrainian military with sufficient artillery ammunition is part of a larger American-led effort to increase its overall combat power.

item.title: Ukraine Asks for More Weapons as U.S. and Allies Meet to Discuss Aid
item.description: Ukraine has a narrow window of time to retake more territory ahead of an expected Russian spring offensive, but to do that it needs weapons like armored vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Two Leopard 2 A6 heavy battle tanks and a Puma infantry fighting vehicle at a military training ground last year in Munster, Germany.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: China’s Dual Crises
item.description: Last year, China’s economy had one of its worst performances in decades. Its population is also shrinking.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Street scene in Guangzhou, China, in 2021.

item.title: British Battery Start-Up Files for Bankruptcy
item.description: The failure of Britishvolt is a blow to Britain’s plans to promote the manufacture of electric cars, and threatens the future of its automotive industry.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:description: Peter Rolton, the executive chairman of Britishvolt, last year at the site of the company’s proposed factory in northeast England.

item.title: England Is Banning Some Single-Use Plastics. Activists Say It’s a Small Step.
item.description: Starting in October, the country will prohibit plastic plates, cutlery and other items. Environmental advocates are pushing for a more comprehensive measure.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Victor
item.media:description: England will prohibit single-use plastic cutlery as part of a wider ban starting in October.

item.title: Belarus Puts Exiled Opposition Leader on Trial for Treason
item.description: Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, now based in Lithuania, denounced the proceedings as a “farce,” adding that her government-appointed defense lawyer had not responded to her attempts at contact.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, Belarus’s main exiled opposition leader, speaking at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, on Tuesday.

item.title: A Wagner Fighter Defects to Norway, Promising to Expose Russian War Crimes
item.description: The rare defection by a former member of the notorious Russian paramilitary force could aid investigations into Moscow’s atrocities.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Henrik Pryser Libell and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: The Norway-Russia border from the Pasvik Valley on the Norwegian side.

item.title: A Better Covid Winter
item.description: Covid hospitalizations have not surged so far this season.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:description: Covid testing in Salt Lake City last month.

item.title: Germany Appoints New Defense Minister as Ukraine War Pressure Mounts
item.description: The appointment of Boris Pistorius comes as Germany faces increasing calls to send Leopard 2 tanks to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Boris Pistorius led the interior ministry in Lower Saxony, Germany’s fourth most populous state.

item.title: Zelensky pushes allies to move faster with aid as fears grow of a new Russian offensive.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: A British Challenger 2 tank participating in a training in Augustdorf, Germany, in 2018. Britain’s defense secretary, Ben Wallace, confirmed plans to send Challenger 2 tanks and other sophisticated military equipment to Ukraine.

item.title: With 50 Dead in Peru, a Referendum on Democracy
item.description: Weeks after the ouster of a leftist president, persistent protests and a mounting death toll have exacerbated widespread disillusionment with the country’s young democracy.
item.dc:creator: Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters blocking the main road between Arequipa and Juliaca, Peru.

item.title: Global Push to Treat HIV Leaves Children Behind
item.description: Sub-Saharan Africa has made steady progress in delivering lifesaving medication to adults, but young patients are harder to reach and 100,000 are dying of AIDS each year.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Malin Fezehai
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times

item.title: Australian Open Bans Russian, Belarusian Flags
item.description: Tennis has struggled with its response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, which Belarus has supported.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A fan holding a Russian flag on Monday, the Australian Open’s first day.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Britain pushes for more aid to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: Death Toll of Russian Strike in Dnipro Rises to 40, Ukraine Says
item.description: The authorities said 34 people remained missing after three days of searching for the living and the dead at an apartment building struck by a Russian missile in Dnipro.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Megan Specia
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency workers clearing rubble on Monday as they looked for victims of a Russian attack on an apartment building in Dnipro.

item.title: Former Afghan Lawmaker Shot Dead at Her Home in Kabul
item.description: The legislator, Mursal Nabizada, was one of a few female parliamentarians who remained in the country after the Western-backed government collapsed and the Taliban seized power.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
item.media:description: Mursal Nabizada, a former Afghan lawmaker, was shot dead by gunmen at her house in Kabul on Sunday.

item.title: European Parliament Focuses on 2 More Lawmakers in Corruption Scandal
item.description: The assembly on Monday began the process of lifting the immunity of two members at the request of the Belgian police in a snowballing corruption investigation involving Qatar.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:description: “The events of last months have led to a need to rebuild trust of the European citizens that we represent,” Roberta Metsola, the president of the European Parliament, told lawmakers on Monday at a session in Strasbourg, France.

item.title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Chinese ‘Zero Covid’ Workers Revolt
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: Zelensky Adviser Says He’ll Resign Over Comments on Dnipro Strike
item.description: In televised comments after a devastating Russian strike in Dnipro on Saturday, the adviser, Oleksii Arestovych, said that the missile had been struck by Ukraine’s air defense system before crashing into an apartment building. He later apologized.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Oleksii Chumachenko/SOPA Images/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Oleksii Arestovych, an adviser to the office of the Ukraine’s president, at the site of a Russian missile attack in central Kyiv in October.

item.title: UK Confirms Plan to Send Tanks to Ukraine
item.description: The U.K. defense secretary said specialty guns, ammunition, drones and other equipment were also part of the package being sent to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: British Challenger 2 tanks during NATO exercises in Adazi, Latvia, in 2019.

item.title: U.K. Government Blocks Scottish Law Making Gender Change Easier
item.description: For the first time, the government in London is blocking legislation approved by the Scottish Parliament, saying the measure on gender identity would undermine U.K.-wide equality law.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Jane Barlow/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Supporters of Scotland’s new gender recognition legislation rallying outside the Scottish Parliament in Edinburgh in December, before a debate on the bill.

item.title: U.N. Confirms More Than 7,000 Civilian Deaths in Ukraine
item.description: The total includes only those that U.N. investigators have been able to corroborate, and does not include the dozens killed in Saturday’s strike on Dnipro.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Nicole Tung for The New York Times
item.media:description: The bodies of five victims of the missile strike in Dnipro, Ukraine, after being retrieved on Sunday.

item.title: Hamas Releases Video That Appears to Show Israeli Missing Since 2014
item.description: If verified as authentic, the footage would provide the first public proof of life of Avera Mengistu, an Israeli citizen who disappeared after walking into Gaza and had been held captive by Hamas.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A banner showing the captive Israeli civilian Avera Mengistu, left picture, near the Erez border crossing on the Israel-Gaza border, last year.

item.title: Armed Insurgents Kidnap 50 Women in Burkina Faso
item.description: The women were abducted while searching for food in a region that has been under a blockade by extremist groups for nearly a year.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: Soldiers patrolling in the Sahel area in 2019 in Burkina Faso.

item.title: In Nepal Crash, Pilot Met the Same Fate as Her Husband 17 Years Before
item.description: Anju Khatiwada, who died on Sunday in a crash in Pokhara, Nepal, decided to become a pilot after her husband’s death in 2006. The family’s calamities are part of a deadly pattern of aviation disasters in Nepal.
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma and Mujib Mashal
item.media:description: Rescuers on Monday recovering the body of a victim who died in a Yeti Airlines plane crash in Pokhara, Nepal, the day before. Seventy-two people were on the flight.

item.title: London Police Officer Admits to 49 Charges of Sexual Abuse, Including Rape
item.description: David Carrick, who worked for the Metropolitan Police, carried out “a relentless campaign” of violence over 17 years, prosecutors said, using his position of authority to manipulate victims.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Jonathan Brady/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Officials at a news conference outside a London court on Monday after David Carrick, a former police officer, had pleaded guilty to sexual offenses against 12 women.

item.title: Christine Lambrecht Resigns as Germany’s Defense Minister
item.description: Christine Lambrecht was a frequent target of criticism, including over German caution on military aid to Ukraine. Chancellor Olaf Scholz had backed her strongly, and may find her hard to replace.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Christine Lambrecht, the departing defense minister, is the most senior official to have resigned from Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government.

item.title: A united Europe weathers crises, but deeper challenges remain.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Families boarding evacuation trains last February in Kramatorsk, Ukraine. Europe is divided about how the war in Ukraine should end.
